Executive summary for Americold San Antonio, TX.



RISK MANAGEMENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following information provided describes the executive summary for Americold San Antonio, TX. risk management release prevention program to comply with the requirements of the EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155- Executive Summary.  The RMP release prevention program for this facility follows the compliance requirements of OSHA 1910.119 process safety management.  The hazard assessment for this process identifies potential off site consequences related to an accidental release of the chemical, anhydrous ammonia that is contained in the process.  A program management system is in place that describes the lines of authority for overall responsibility, implementation and maintenance of the release prevention program elements.

 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PREPAREDNESS

The AmeriCold San Antonio, TX. facility abides by emergency procedures that are required by OSHA 1910.38 emergency action plan. However this process is covered by hazwoper 1910.120 in the event of a chemical accident that requires emergency response.  The emergency response plan is coordinated with Bexar County hazmat.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 



To save lives.

To minimize off site impacts and avoid injuries.

To protect the environment.

To minimize property damage.



AmeriCold maintains a (safety) committee and has employees that are involve with assigned rolls in the facility emergency action plan.   The Facility Service Manager and Plant Manager are responsible for maintaining the process safety program that includes the emergency action plan.  Preventing accidental releases and protecting the environment from damage due to off site consequences are primary objectives of the risk management program. 



The emergency plan includes the instructions for emergency notifications, safe evacuation and procedures to handle small releases.  To respond effecti

vely in a hazardous materials emergency situations involving a release, employees that are trained in managing the anhydrous ammonia systems are on call 24/7.  The emergency plan is reviewed and updated at least annually.  This Plan is in place to ensure the safety of the employees, the neighboring community, the environment and to sustain compliance with regulatory requirements to provide a work place that is safe.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The AmeriCold San Antonio facility is a public refrigerated warehouse SIC 4222 that stores and distributes a variety of food products for its customers. The facility has three (3) refrigeration processes, each consisting of industrial grade machinery with piping, valves, ASME certified vessels, cooling air units and refrigeration compressors.  This equipment utilizes anhydrous ammonia, a natural refrigerant for the refrigeration systems. Changes in pressure through the refrigeration cycle relate directly to changes in temperature of the refrigerant. For example, lowering the pressure of a refrigerant lowers its temperature. Low pressure, (cold) The ammonia refrigerant absorb heat through storage room air units.  Removal of the heat from the room provides the refrigeration affect.  Removal of ambient heat from products in turn reduces the spoilage and allows for extended storage of food products.



Anhydrous ammonia (CAS #766-41-7) Refrigerant grade, pure anhydrous ammonia is the chemical in the process that is reglated at this address.  In low concentrations ammonia is easily detectable and has a pungent odor that makes it ideal as a refrigerant because of this self alarming characteristic.



Three individual refrigeration systems are present at the Americold San Antonio facility.  

Each are seperated by reasonable distance and are not inter-connected.  Each process resides in different building structures with seperate process equipment.  



One process at this address has the potent

ial to exceed the threshold planning quantity(TPQ) of 10,000  This refrigeration system, identified as ER2 could contain a maximum intended inventory(MII) of 13000 pounds.



The two other refrigeration systems at this location below the RMP planning quantity are identified as ER1 with an MII of 8700 lbs, and ER3 with an MII of 2400 lbs. 



Combined an estimated maximum intended inventory of 37,100 lbs are present at this address.    



Ammonia is listed and reportable as an extremely hazardous substances, EHS.  In the event the operating charge of ammonia in ER2 is increased, compliance is required under the the clean air act section CAA112r, RMP- Accidental Release Prevention Program, and OSHA 1910.119 PSM program three and section 302, 304, 311, 312 of the emergency planning community right to know act-EPCRA.  



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC AMMONIA RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



To assure safety, this process is maintained in accordance with industry standards and best practices, including Americold corporate policies and procedures.  Americold San Antonio adheres to the guidelines of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).  The standards and guidelines include the following but are not limited to:



IIAR Ammonia Data Book                                                                                                       IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

IIAR Bulletin R1, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



In conjunction with the RMP release prevention program, the OSHA 1910.119 PSM program is adopted as the culture in which this facility manages its compliance for the program elements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  

The release prevention program integrates the elements of process safety management that includes, employee participation,

process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor qualifications, pre start up review, mechanical integrity, hot work, management of change, incident investigation, emergency planning, compliance audits.  This process has no trade secrets.  Of these elements mechanical integrity inspections and routine preventive maintenance procedures are on scheduled intervals consistent with manufacturers to prevent process equipment failures that could potentially result in an accidental release of ammonia.  Recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices are adhered to and followed to maintain the process equipment in safe operating condition.  

The process hazard analysis (PHA) study aimed at identifying process hazards and solutions for preventing potential releases, injury and environmental damage.  The study focused on improvements that help sustain a safer operation of the process at this facility.  PHA recommendations receive careful consideration, especially when improved safety for the process is achievable.  Every effort is given by the PHA team to identify reasonable solutions and address all recommendations in an expeditious fashion. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no ammonia releases in the last 5 years that met the five year accident, RMP reportable criteria.  No evacuation of employees or off site evacuations have occurred.  No injuries, deaths, or serious property damage or off site environmental impacts resulted from any accidents involving an ammonia release resulted at this facility.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The AmeriCold San Antonio facility has an Emergency Action Plan in place according to the requirements of 1910.38 along with a fire prevention plan.  Emergency response for the facility is coordinated with Bexar County Hazmat, and the local Fire Department. The facility has trained employees to assist the local fire department and hazmat team during any emergency situation

s.  The refrigeration employees on staff received hazmat technician training for emergency response.  The hazmat technician employees receive 8 hour refresher training on an annual basis.  Emergency team members receive occupational screening, medical evaluations, and are fit tested for the proper use of respiratory protection equipment.  



The facility conducts annual evacuation drills to ensure all employees understand the emergency evacuation, and shelter in place procedures for different emergencies that can occur.  In addition, the local Fire Department tours the facility for compliance with jurisdictional fire safety requirements.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

During the review of the Process Safety Management program at this facility, the Process Hazard Analysis study and the mechanical integrity inspections generated recommendations and measures to improve safety at the AmeriCold San Antonio facility.  The findings become recognized action items that are entered into a schedule and the status to completion is addressed in a timely fashion.  Upgrades to the process that were targeted as improvement projects are listed below. 

1. New ammonia piping and low temperature vessel insulation and vapor barrier systems. 

2. Replacement of an evaporative condenser cooling tower 

3. Additional pipe labeling
